abstract_summ: These findings suggest that elevated serum S100B levels on day 3 and the dynamic changes of serum S100B levels from day three to one were more associated with brain dysfunction and mortality than that on day 1 in patients with sepsis.The SAE group showed a significantly higher APACHE II score, SOFA scores, length of ICU stay, 28-day and 180-day mortality, serum S100B levels on day 1 and day 3.BACKGROUND: Examination of serum lactate level and its changes, as an indicator of tissue oxygenation, as well as level of creatine kinase (CK) inhibitors, as a factor of mortality which partially expresses heart, brain, and muscle damage, may be considered as tools to determine prognosis in critically ill patients.CONCLUSIONS: In poisoned patients, serum lactate and CK can be used as possible prognostic factors because they rapidly increase in the serum and are easily detectable.59 patients were diagnosed with SAE and the rest 45 patients were diagnosed with non-SAE.
title_summ: Potential prognostic roles of serum lactate and Creatine kinase levels in poisoned patientsThe dynamic change of serum S100B levels from day 1 to day 3 is more associated with sepsis-associated encephalopathyMetabolic disturbances and inflammatory dysfunction predict severity of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19): a retrospective study
title_abstract_phrases: These findings suggest that elevated serum S100B levels on day 3 and the dynamic changes of serum S100B levels from day three to one were more associated with brain dysfunction and mortality than that on day 1 in patients with sepsis.The SAE group showed a significantly higher APACHE II score, SOFA scores, length of ICU stay, 28-day and 180-day mortality, serum S100B levels on day 1 and day 3.Potential prognostic roles of serum lactate and Creatine kinase levels in poisoned patientsBACKGROUND: Examination of serum lactate level and its changes, as an indicator of tissue oxygenation, as well as level of creatine kinase (CK) inhibitors, as a factor of mortality which partially expresses heart, brain, and muscle damage, may be considered as tools to determine prognosis in critically ill patients.The dynamic change of serum S100B levels from day 1 to day 3 is more associated with sepsis-associated encephalopathyWe investigated the role of dynamic changes of serum levels S100B protein in brain injury and poor outcome of sepsis.CONCLUSIONS: In poisoned patients, serum lactate and CK can be used as possible prognostic factors because they rapidly increase in the serum and are easily detectable.
